III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation This past Friday, youth was stressed out and beat her head on a
brick wall gashing it open. Youth's parents were notified that it was
a small cut. On Saturday, youth was observed with a wound that
was concerning. After requests made, youth was sent to Zeeland
hospital. Upon evaluation it was determined that if youth would
have been seen on Friday that she would have received staples
for the wound. Today youth hit her own head on a sink and has
opened her original wound. Youth was assessed by medical staff
at the facility, and it was assessed youth did not need staples.
There is a concern that youth may be assessed incorrectly due to
the incident that previously took place with youth not going to the
hospital during the first incident. There is additional concern that
youth continues to harm herself and that she will injure herself
severely while in the care of the detention center.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A’s Father (Father) was interviewed via phone on
2/24/25. Father reported when Youth A gets overwhelmed or
stressed, she bangs her head on things, and this reaction has
been happening since she was a toddler. Father reported he
received a call from Supervisor 2 late on 2/14/25 (about 3-4 hours
after the incident occurred) that Youth A hit her head on the brick
wall out of frustration. Father reported he was told it resulted in a
minor cut on her head, which did not require medical services.
Father reported he didn’t think anything more of it and proceeded
with his weekly Saturday evening visit on 2/15/25. Father reported
in the afternoon on 2/15/25, Youth A called him and reported she
had been trying to get a hold of him for days, and through the
behavior rewards program, she purchased a phone call to speak
with him on 2/13/25. Father reported Youth A said she told staff it
was very urgent she speak with him, but she wasn’t granted a
phone call. Father reported Youth A told him she banged her head
on 2/14/25 and if staff would have listened to her and let her talk
to him, she wouldn’t have banged her head. Father reported it is
well known by all employees at the facility Youth A is not well as
she is a repeat offender for doing the same thing recurrently.
Father reported when he went to visit Youth A at the facility in the
evening on 2/15/25, Youth A had her hair parted to the side.
Father said when she moved her hair over, he saw a ½ inch gash
2

on the top of her head and took a picture. Father reported as soon
as he saw the mark on her head, he made a scene and
demanded she be seen at the hospital because the injury clearly
needed staples. Father reported although he’s not a medical
professional, it was clear to him the wound was large enough and
deep enough, it needed to be physically closed to heal. Father
reported he was referred to speak to Nurse 1 as she was the one
who treated Youth A on 2/14/25. Father reported Nurse 1 was the
most arrogant, sarcastic medical professional he’s ever spoken to
in his life. Father reported Nurse 1 defended her position to not
send Youth A to the hospital on 2/14/25, and with a smile on her
face said, “I’m the medical professional, not you”. Father reported
he left the visitation, went to the parking lot, and immediately
called the Sherriff’s Department. Father reported he met with an
officer in the parking lot and the officer told him the situation was
out of their hands because it’s a separate entity. Father reported
the officer connected him with the Chief Administrator (CA) of the
facility. Father reported he was in the parking lot dealing with this
for approximately 4-5 hours going back and forth with CA. Father
reported CA told him he needed authorization from the medical
staff to take Youth A to the hospital and he was working on
obtaining the authorization. Father reported at approximately 1:00
AM on 2/16/25, the facility finally brought Youth A to Zeeland
Hospital, and he met them there. Father reported Staff 1
accompanied Youth A to the hospital and was in the room with
them while Doctor assessed Youth A’s injury. Father reported
after the assessment, Doctor stated since the wound was almost 2
days old, and it had already begun to scab over, it would not be
wise to pick the scab open to use glue or stitches to close it.
Father reported Doctor said if Youth A had been taken to the
emergency room on 2/14/25 after the incident occurred, he would
have most definitely used staples to close the wound. Father
reported Doctor said if Youth A had received staples, she would
have been able to regrow hair in that spot, but because she didn’t
receive staples, the likeliness of hair regrowth in the area was
zero.
Father reported on 2/19/25, he received a phone call from
Supervisor 3 informing him Youth A hit her head on the sink in her
room, reopened the wound and there was no longer a scab.
Father asked why Youth A wasn’t being taken to the hospital to
receive staples this time. For the next couple hours, Father spoke
to nursing staff. Father reported Nurse 1 was the nurse who
completed the initial evaluation and assessment for this incident,
and she was the same nurse who completed the assessment on
2/14/25. Father reported he wanted a second opinion, and the
3

head nurse (couldn’t remember her name) backed up Nurse 1’s
assessment. Father reported he was told multiple nurses had
examined her and all concluded Youth A did not need further
medical treatment.
Father reported on 2/21/25, he was called and told Youth A hit her
head again. Father reported he saw her on 2/22/25 and Youth A
only had a very small wound on her head, so he understood why
she wasn’t taken to the hospital that time.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/24/25.
Youth A reported when she gets upset, she bangs her head on
whatever is near her or available, and this has been happening
since way before she came to the facility. Youth A reported when
she bangs her head, she is fully aware of what she is doing and
the consequences of doing it. Youth A reported she is not sure
how she feels about the medical treatment at the facility. Youth A
reported it’s hit or miss whether you get a nurse who shows
genuine care/concern and wants to help (i.e. Nurse 3) or whether
you get a nurse who doesn’t care and seems to just be there for
the money (i.e. Nurse 1).
Youth A reported on 2/14/25 she was upset and wanted to talk to
Father. Youth A reported she asked staff (couldn’t remember who)
to talk to Father because she was upset, and said if she couldn’t
talk to him, she was going to hurt herself. Youth A reported
approximately 10 minutes later, she began banging her head and
she banged her head for about 10 minutes straight. Youth A
reported Staff 3 entered the room, saw Youth A bleeding, and
went to get a supervisor. Youth A reported within minutes,
Supervisor 2 and Staff 3 entered the room. Supervisor 2 contacted
nursing and requested someone come assess Youth A. Youth A
reported Nurse 1 met with her and said there was a gash at the
front of her hairline. Youth A reported Nurse 1 cleaned the wound
and said nothing else needed to be done. Youth A reported Nurse
1 asked Supervisor 2 if he thought it needed to be glued, and they
both concluded it didn’t need to be. Youth A reported they left the
room, and she went to sleep. Youth A reported the next morning
(2/15/25), she was still feeling upset, but it wasn’t as bad, so she
went about her day. Youth A reported Father came to visit her at
approximately 7:30 PM. Youth A reported Father saw the injury on
her head and he became angry because he said the injury looked
bad, and worse than what Supervisor 2 told him over the phone.
Youth A reported Father told her she should have received
stitches. Youth A reported Father complained to the staff
(unknown) who was in the visitation room, and then said he was
4

going to call the cops and get an ambulance to come to the facility
and assess her. Youth A reported Father felt they were medically
neglecting her treatment. Youth A reported around midnight on
2/16/25, she was taken by ambulance to the hospital and was
escorted by Staff 1. Youth A reported Father met them at the
hospital. Youth A reported at the hospital, Doctor said if Youth A
would have come to the hospital on 2/14/25, she would have
received stitches. However, now it was too late for Youth A to get
stitches because the wound was already scabbing over, and if
Doctor opened the wound to give her stitches, it would have
gotten infected. Youth A reported Doctor gave her bacterial
ointment to take with her, but that’s all he did.
Youth A reported on 2/19/25, she became upset and banged her
head on the sink in her room. Youth A reported Staff 4 came to do
checks around 9:45-10:00 PM and she told Staff 4 she felt like
hurting herself and wanted to die. Youth A reported she told Staff
4 she needed to talk to someone. Youth A reported Staff 4 said,
“No don’t say that. I have to go right now to finish my checks”, and
then he left. Youth A reported no one came to talk to her or check
on her, so she banged her head because she was still upset.
Youth A reported approximately 15 minutes after Staff 4 came,
Staff 2 came to complete a check and didn’t seem to know Youth
A was upset or what was going on. Youth A reported Staff 2 asked
if she needed to talk to someone and she said yes. Youth A
reported shortly after, Supervisor 1 came to talk to her, and she
told Supervisor 1 about Staff 4. Youth A reported Supervisor 1
called Nurse 3 to come assess her head because she re-opened
the same wound from 2/14/25. Youth A reported Nurse 3 cleaned
the wound and said it was fine. Youth A reported on 2/20/25,
Father came to visit her and said the wound was looking better.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 2/24/25. CA reported he spoke with Father on 2/15/25
after Father had visitation with Youth A. Father stated he wasn’t
leaving the facility grounds until Youth A went to the hospital. CA
reported he spoke with Nurse 1 and Nurse Supervisor and they
both reported there was no medical reason for Youth A to go to
the hospital. Nurse 1 and Nurse Supervisor reported if CA wanted
to send her to the hospital anyways, they would approve it. CA
reported he asked for the approval, it was provided, and Youth A
was sent to the hospital via ambulance.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 3/6/25. Staff 1 reported
she works 3rd shift and was on shift for the early morning hours of
2/16/25, and she accompanied Youth A to the hospital. Staff 1
5

reported Youth A bangs her head frequently when stressed. Staff
1 reported Father felt Youth A needed to go to the hospital to get
stitches, so the facility followed through at Father’s request. Staff 1
reported Doctor said everything with Youth A’s wound looked
good. Doctor said he didn’t want to open the wound to give Youth
A stitches because opening the scab would leave the wound at
more risk for infection. Doctor reported if Youth A was brought to
the emergency room on 2/14/25, he likely would have put in
stitches. However, Doctor reported how the wound was cared for
was sufficient and didn’t have any concerns about Youth A not
going to the hospital on 2/14/25. Staff 1 reported Doctor said
Youth A may have more trouble growing hair in the area without
having stitches, but regardless of the treatment, Youth A would
have a scar indefinitely. Staff 1 reported after Doctor said this,
Father said, “you heard she won’t be able to grow hair there now,
right?”. Staff 1 reported Doctor never said Youth A couldn’t grow
hair in the area, but said she would have trouble growing hair
there. Staff 1 reported nursing at the facility has told Youth A
repeatedly if she continues to bang her head, she will continue to
re-open the wound and continue to have a scar. Staff 1 reported
Doctor provided Youth A with anti-bacterial ointment.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 3/21/25. Staff 2 reported
on 2/19/25, he went to complete checks, and he found Youth A on
her bed crying. Staff 2 reported he asked Youth A if she needed
anything, and Youth A stated she wanted to speak with someone.
Staff 2 reported he needed to finish checks, so he let Supervisor 1
know Youth A wanted to speak with someone. Staff 2 reported
Supervisor 1 talked to Youth A, but Staff 2 wasn’t present for the
conversation. Staff 2 reported when she saw Youth A, she was
not banging her head. Staff 2 reported when he saw Youth A,
there was no blood on the wall or on her head.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 3/20/25. Staff 3 reported
on 2/14/25, Youth A took a time-out during the middle of gym
class because she was upset over not getting a phone call with
Father. Staff 3 reported Youth A was informed staff were busy and
were not able to take the time to make a phone call with her at
that time. Staff 3 reported the camera for Youth A’s room kept
glitching on the control board. Staff 3 reported she then listened to
the speaker in Youth A’s room and heard Youth A say something
about wanting to kill herself, so Staff 3 went to check on Youth A.
Staff 3 reported as she approached Youth A’s room, she heard
banging and crying. Staff 3 reported she witnessed Youth A
banging her head, so Staff 3 verbally de-escalated her and tried to
find out what was going on. Staff 3 reported Youth A was trying to
6

respond but wasn’t forming coherent sentences. Staff 3 reported
she went to get Supervisor 2, informed him what was happening,
and then retrieved sanitary items to take care of Youth A’s wound
and the blood on the wall. Staff 3 reported when she returned to
Youth A’s room, Youth A expressed she was upset with herself
because she hadn’t banged her head in a while. Staff 3 reported
she gave Youth A some paper towels and asked her to keep
pressure on the wound. Staff 3 reported she cleaned the wall
while she talked to Youth A. Staff 3 reported Youth A said she was
initially upset about not being able to make a phone call, but said
there was something else too (didn’t say what). Staff 3 reported
continued to talk to her until Supervisor 2 came to the room.
Supervisor 2 instructed Staff 3 to take Youth A to the small
conference room to meet with nursing, so Staff 3 did. Staff 3
reported the gash on Youth A’s head looked pretty deep, but it
was hard to tell because there was blood all around it and it wasn’t
clean. Staff 3 reported she did not see the wound once Nurse 3
cleaned it because she left the room as soon as Nurse 3 entered
the room to treat Youth A.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 3/26/25. Staff 4 reported
he saw Youth A on 2/19/25 while he was doing checks. Staff 4
reported Youth A was crying, and she had been crying for several
hours at that point. Staff 4 reported Youth A never said she
wanted to die or kill herself. Staff 4 reported he did his check, but
he didn’t interact with her. Staff 4 reported all staff and supervisors
were aware of Youth A being upset since she had been crying for
so long.
Nurse 1 was interviewed via phone on 3/24/25. Nurse 1
reported Youth A has a history of hitting her head ever since she
was a toddler and the whole area is hit up from the repeated
trauma. She reported there’s been an ongoing issue with Youth A
banging her head multiple times over a 2-week period. Nurse 1
reported Youth A was seen by multiple nurses at the facility,
Physician Assistant, the emergency room, etc. Nurse 1 reported
on 2/14/25, she was called because Youth A banged her head on
the wall. Nurse 1 reported she assessed Youth A’s wound,
completed a neuro check, and took her vitals. Nurse 1 reported
Youth A had a small abrasion to the center-top-front of Youth A’s
hairline. Nurse 1 reported the injury wasn’t deep or wide enough
to need sutures. Nurse 1 reported she cleaned the wound and put
on steri-strips to cover it. Nurse 1 reported there was no way to
put a band aid on the wound because it was in Youth A’s hair, and
they do not have access to skin glue at the facility. Nurse 1
reported she educated Youth A on coping skills, told Youth A not
7

to pick at it or mess with it, and told Youth A how to care for the
wound to prevent infection. Nurse 1 reported Youth A has a
history of picking wounds. Nurse 1 reported she wasn’t present on
2/15/25, but Nurse 1 was told Nurse 4 saw Youth A on 2/15/25
because Youth A had been picking at and messing with the
wound. Nurse 1 reported Father saw Youth A the evening of
2/15/25, and she wasn’t sure how the wound changed between
2/14/25 and 2/15/25 when Father saw her and Youth A went to
the hospital. Nurse 1 reported she has worked in emergency
rooms before and has the knowledge/background to assess
whether a wound needs sutures or not. Nurse 1 reported she was
positive the wound she assessed on 2/14/25 did not require
sutures. Nurse 1 reported the next time she saw Youth A was on
2/19/25 because Youth A banged her head on the sink in her
room and the wound reopened. Nurse 1 reported the wound
looked completely different on 2/19/25 than it did on 2/14/25.
Nurse 1 reported it had various stages of healing and looked more
like Youth A had dug into it or picked at it because it no longer
looked like a straight line and was more pitted out. Nurse 1
reported Father was not happy with her assessing Youth A again
on 2/19/24, so Nurse 2 was asked to complete a second opinion.
Nurse 2 agreed Youth A did not need to go to the hospital to treat
the wound.
Nurse 2 was interviewed via phone on 3/24/25. Nurse 2
reported on 2/19/25 she was called for a second opinion to look at
the wound on Youth A’s head because Father was not pleased
with the first opinion provided. Nurse 2 reported she didn’t
remember who provided the first opinion. Nurse 2 reported Youth
A had a cut on her head, but it was clean, and it was not an open
wound needing medical attention. Nurse 2 agreed with the first
opinion and concluded Youth A did not require outside medical
attention.
Nurse 3 was interviewed via phone on 3/18/25. Nurse 3
reported she was called by Supervisor 1 to address Youth A’s
wound after Youth A banged her head on the sink in her room.
Nurse 3 reported she could not remember the exact date she was
called because Youth A has reopened the same wound multiple
times due to her repeated head banging. Nurse 3 reported Youth
A also frequently picks at scabs and reopens them. Nurse 3
reported she cleaned Youth A’s wound, put Bacitracin ointment on
it, and explained the side effects to Youth A if Youth A continues
to bang her head. Nurse 3 reported there was no reason to send
Youth A to the hospital for treatment because the wound was not
big or deep enough to warrant further care.
8

Nurse 4 was interviewed via phone on 3/24/25. Nurse 4
reported she saw Youth A on 2/15/25 because Youth A had been
picking at the wound on her head. Nurse 4 reported Youth A’s
head wound is never going to go away or fully heal because Youth
A keeps banging her head in the same spot, keeps picking at the
wound, and keeps reopening it. Nurse 4 reported the tissue
integrity of the wound has been broken down so much, there’s no
possible way for it to heal fully. Nurse 4 reported when she saw
Youth A on 2/15/25, the head wound was not wide open and was
not bleeding. Nurse 4 reported the wound was a little open from
Youth A picking at it, but there was nothing that could be done.
Youth A denied being in any pain. Nurse 4 reported she couldn’t
put a band aid on the wound because it is on Youth A’s hair line
and the band aid would not stick. Nurse 4 reported she offered
Youth A steri-strips to cover the wound, but Youth A declined the
steri-strips because she said she always just takes them off
anyways. Youth A accepted Nurse 4 putting Bacitracin ointment
on the wound, but that was all that was done. Nurse 4 reported
she educated Youth A on how to care for the wound, went over
appropriate coping skills with her, and discussed the reasons
Youth A needed to stop picking at the wound.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via phone on 3/6/25. Supervisor
1 reported she wasn’t involved in the incident on 2/19/25 when
Youth A banged her head on the sink. However, Supervisor 1
reported she was involved in an incident on 2/21/25 where Youth
A also banged her head on the sink in her room. Supervisor 1
reported she went to speak with Youth A per Youth A’s request.
Supervisor 1 reported when she got to the room, Youth A had
already banged her head on the sink, and it looked like Youth A
knocked the scab on the wound loose. Supervisor 1 reported
Nurse 3 came to assess the injury. Nurse 3 treated the wound
with saline, gauze, and Bacitracin ointment. Nurse 3 educated
Youth A to stop picking at the wound, keep her fingers away from
the wound, let it heal, and provided her with some coping skills.
Nurse 3 reported she didn’t put steri-strips on the wound because
of Youth A’s history of removing the steri-strips and picking at
scabs.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 3/26/25. Supervisor
2 reported Youth A’s coping skill for when she is upset is to hit her
head against something, not for the purpose of self-harm, but
more for release. Supervisor 2 reported on 2/14/25, he was
meeting with another youth when Staff 3 informed him Youth A
was bleeding from the top of her head. Supervisor 2 reported
9

Youth A has an existing scar on the spot due to the wound
continuously being reopened from trauma and Youth A picking at
it. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A is constantly told not to pick at
the wound, but she does anyways. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A
had blood on her head and there was blood on the wall.
Supervisor 2 reported she instructed Staff 3 what cleaning stuff to
get. Supervisor 2 contacted nursing and requested assistance.
Nurse 3 reported and Supervisor 2 told her what happened.
Supervisor 2 reported it is not his position to make the call
whether to send a youth out for hospital care unless the injury or
situation is life-threatening. Supervisor 2 reported Nurse 3 cleaned
Youth A’s wound and put steri-strips on it. Supervisor 2 reported
Nurse 3 instructed Youth A not to remove the steri-strips and not
to pick at the wound, so it could heal properly. Supervisor 2
reported Youth A ended up picking off the steri-strips and picked
at the wound within the next few days and admitted she did so to
staff. Supervisor 2 reported on 2/15/25, Father visited Youth A at
the facility, and he was not happy with the medical care Youth A
received. Father felt the wound was larger and more open than he
was told on the phone and felt she should have been sent to the
hospital to treat it.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Picture of Youth A’s wound dated 2/15/25 was obtained
from Father.
• Incident report dated 2/14/25 authored by Supervisor 2 and
Staff 3 was consistent with their interviews.
• Corewell Health Zeeland Emergency Room paperwork
dated 2/16/25 authored by Doctor states Youth A was seen
due to a small scalp laceration that happened on 2/14/25.
Wound (approximately 1 cm) is already healing, and Doctor
did not feel staples should be placed at the time of the ER
visit. Doctor noted there would be greater risk for infection if
staples were placed. Doctor discussed with Father if Youth
A presented on the day of the laceration, the ER would
have likely placed 1-2 staples. Doctor recommended topical
antibiotic ointment. Doctor advised Youth A would likely
have a small scar in the area and may have some difficulty
growing hair from that area. Doctor discussed this would
have likely been the result regardless of when Youth A
went to the hospital. Recommended ointment be applied
twice daily for the next 7-10 days.
10

• Incident report dated 2/16/25 authored by Supervisor 1 and
Staff 5. Youth A had visitation with Father on 2/15/25.
Father expressed to Staff 5 he was not satisfied with the
level of medical care Youth A received following the
incident on 2/14/25. Father stated Youth A not having
stitches was unacceptable. Father was vocal and
antagonistic, swearing, and being disrespectful towards
Staff 5. Father met with Nurse 1 and scolded Nurse 1 like a
child. The rest of the report was consistent with CA,
Supervisor 2, and Nurse 1’s interviews.
• Incident report dated 2/19/25 authored by Supervisor 3.
Supervisor 3 reported to Youth A’s room due to Youth A’s
head bleeding. Youth A reported she hit her head on the
sink, which caused the top of her forehead to bleed.
Supervisor 2 attempted to contact medical at 8:23 PM but
there was no answer. CA was notified of event. Supervisor
3 called medical again at 8:51 PM. Nurse 1 responded and
then came to assess Youth A. Nurse 1 cleaned the wound
and put anti-bacterial ointment on it. Supervisor 3 brought
Youth A ice to put on the wound. Supervisor 2 called Father
and informed him of the incident. Father was angry and
disappointed by the medical care Youth A was receiving at
the facility. Supervisor 3 spoke with Father and Father
expressed he felt Youth A should go to the hospital.
Supervisor 3 offered for another nurse to evaluate the
wound, and Father agreed. Nurse 2 arrived and assessed
the wound. Nurse 2 reported wound was intact, not
bleeding and just needed anti-bacterial ointment moving
forward. Supervisor 3 notified Father of the result and
Father was unhappy, so his number was provided to Nurse
Supervisor.
• Nursing notes 2/14/25-2/21/25:
o 2/14/25 at 8:00 PM – Nurse 1 responded to incident
of Youth A banging her head on the wall. Nurse 1
documented an approximate 12mm x 3 mm
laceration to center frontal lobe just inside hairline.
Bleeding controlled and cleansed. Placed 4 steri-
strips to wound and provided ice pack. Encouraged
coping skills and advised Youth A not to bang her
head.
o 2/15/25 at 5:12 PM – Nurse 4 responded to assess
Youth A because Youth A was digging at the wound
on her forehead. Youth A admitted digging at her
wound. Nurse 4 performed wound care (cleaned
11

wound, applied Bacitracin ointment) and placed
follow-up task for youth to be seen by provider.
Nurse 4 was unable to place a band aid due to
wound being in Youth A’s hair.
o 2/15/25 at 7:50 PM – Nurse 1 responded as Father
requested to speak with her. Father wanted to know
why Youth A was not sent to ER for sutures on
2/14/25. Father yelled at Nurse 1 stating, “My
daughter needs stitches!”, “That’s a gaping hole in
her head!”, “I want your name and information!”, “I’m
going to get a lawyer and sue the fuck out of you!”,
and “I’m going to leave here and call the police and
an ambulance”. Nurse 1 asked Father to calm down.
Nurse 1 informed Father when Youth A was
assessed yesterday, abrasion was not severe
enough to need sutures, and unless Youth A was
messing with it, it still should not need sutures.
Father stood with his fists clenched and yelled, “Are
you fucking stupid?” and “You are a fucking ignorant
stupid bitch!”. Nurse 1 again asked Father to calm
down. Father said, “I’m going to sue you, you dumb
ignorant bitch!” and “Get out of my face”. Nurse 1
told Father she was no longer going to speak with
him and walked away.
o 2/15/25 at 11:30 PM – Nurse 1 spoke with CA. CA
informed Nurse 1 Father requested Youth A no
longer receive treatment from any of the facility’s
medical staff. Father contacted the police and
demanded his daughter be sent to the ER for
sutures. Father stated he would be getting a lawyer
and filing a lawsuit. Nurse 1 informed CA based on
assessment of Youth A on 2/14/25, abrasion was not
severe enough for sutures, and given the time since
the incident, the ER would not suture it now
anyways. Nurse 1 offered to contact Nurse
Supervisor and CA requested that be completed.
o 2/15/25 at 11:36 PM – Nurse Supervisor called CA
and due to Father’s escalating behavior, decision
was made to send Youth A to the local ER.
o 2/16/25 at 2:59 AM – Nurse 1 was informed Youth A
returned from ER with Bacitracin orders for wound.
o 2/18/25 at 3:25 PM – Youth A was evaluated by

Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, the facility followed their policy
regarding emergency medical treatment and is providing
appropriate medical care to Youth A. Multiple nurses and medical
professionals assessed Youth A’s wound between 2/14/25-
2/21/25 and none of them felt stitches or further medical treatment
was warranted. Although Doctor stated if Youth A went to the ER,
they likely would have placed 1-2 stitches over the wound, Doctor
never stated Youth A should have presented at the ER on
2/14/25. This was confirmed by Staff 1’s interview as well as the
ER discharge paperwork.
There is no information to support Youth A will injure herself more
severely due to being placed at the facility. According to reports
from Youth A, Father, and multiple facility employees, Youth A has
been banging her head since she was a toddler and continues to
reopen or reinjure the same area repeatedly. Despite Youth A
being educated not to bang her head or touch the wound after
injury, Youth A admits to continued picking at the wound, digging
at the wound, and removing steri-strips placed on the wound.
